item.title: Hearthstone and Warcraft Rumble developers unionize to combat 'instability and unfair conditions'
item.content:encoded:
Chris Kerr, Senior Editor, News, GameDeveloper.com

October 17, 2025

2 Min Read

A majority of Hearthstone and Warcraft Rumble developers have formed a union with the Communications Workers of America (CWA). The newly-organised unit will become members of CWA Local 9510 in Irvine, California.

Activision Blizzard parent company Microsoft has recognized the union, which includes over 100 workers including software engineers, artists, quality assurance testers and producers.

Thousands of Microsoft employees, including many within Activision Blizzard, have unionized in recent years in a bid to secure better working conditions and take charge of their destiny amid a wave of mass layoffs, project cancellations, and studio closures.

Earlier this week, for instance, more than 400 employees within Blizzard's Platform & Technology department successfully voted to unionize. Back in August, over 450 Diablo developers also formed a union under the CWA. 

Prior to that, a group of more than 500 Blizzard Entertainment employees—including the entire World of Warcraft development team—established a wall-to-wall union to "raise industry-wide expectations for pay, benefits and respect for workers’ rights." 

Those Hearthstone and Warcraft Rumble developers who chose to unionize now hope to follow in the footsteps of their colleagues in fighting for a brighter future.

Related:Former Santa Monica Studio boss says major publishers need to diversify beyond triple-A

"Whether we are fighting for layoff protections, security for our remote workers, or reduced wage gaps, the pressures we face are making it harder to create the high-quality work we care about," said organizing committee member and senior 2D artist Uriah Voth. "Organizing gives us the opportunity to empower ourselves, and challenge the instability and unfair conditions that undermine us."

CWA Local 9510 President Jason Justice said today's news is more proof that "creativity and collective power can go hand-in-hand."

"These are some of the most talented developers and artists in the industry, and their decision to form a union sends a clear message that building great games starts with respecting those who are behind them," they added.

item.title: Report: Nintendo to produce up to 25 million Switch 2 units by March 2026
item.content:encoded:
Newsbrief: Nintendo has reportedly asked suppliers to manufacture up to 25 million Switch 2 units to be ready to hit the market by March 2026.

That report comes from Bloomberg News, which notes that the company is on track to sell about 20 million of its next-generation portable console by the end of fiscal year 2025. According to analyst firm Circana, the Switch 2 is pacing well ahead of its predecessor, selling about 77 percent more units in the same 2-month window after release.

Omdia senior analyst James McWhirter credited the "unique" status of the console market in Japan as a key factor for Nintendo's optimism. "Nintendo's subsidized hardware pricing, which extends even to peripherals, puts Switch 2 at a significant pricing advantage over PS5 and even the entry-level LCD Steam Deck model," he said in a statement to Game Developer. He noted that starting with this quarter Nintendo has the opportunity to begin appealing to a wider audience now that it's sated the early adopters.

For more information, be sure to read the full story on Bloomberg.

Game Developer and Omdia are sibling organizations under Informa.
